segments.speaker: Great-Granddaughter
segments.text: Hey guys, so today I'm here with my great-grandmother and I call her Gigi and I'm going to be doing an interview with her today. Do you want to introduce yourself?

segments.speaker: Gigi (Mary Shane Bird)
segments.text: And I am Mary Shane Bird and I am 100 years old. I'm still up walking around and this is my great-granddaughter.

segments.speaker: Great-Granddaughter
segments.text: So Gigi wanted to add one more thing to our video. Go ahead.

segments.speaker: Gigi (Mary Shane Bird)
segments.text: I just had my birthday in December and I have 16 great-grandchildren and one great-great-grandchild.

segments.speaker: Gigi (Mary Shane Bird)
segments.text: I'm a very lucky grandmother, great-grandmother, and great-great-grandmother.

segments.speaker: Great-Granddaughter
segments.text: Yeah, let's just jump right in with the video. Okay, so my first question is, what is your earliest memory and what made that event memorable?

segments.speaker: Gigi (Mary Shane Bird)
segments.text: I think my earliest memory when I was a baby, family was having dinner and in the kitchen next to the living room where we had a fireplace because that was the only heat we had.

segments.speaker: Gigi (Mary Shane Bird)
segments.text: And they put me in a big rocking chair in front of the fireplace and I had never said a word. I was three months old and I hadn't made a sound in my life. And all of a sudden while they're eating dinner, I let out a yell and they thought that the fire had burned me.

segments.speaker: Gigi (Mary Shane Bird)
segments.text: But me and my two brothers said she'd never shut up since. It was the first time she'd opened her mouth and she hadn't shut up since then.

segments.speaker: Great-Granddaughter
segments.text: Okay, so next question. What do you think about today's technology compared to kind of the technology that you had when you were growing up?

segments.speaker: Gigi (Mary Shane Bird)
segments.text: Well, I think it's amazing the technology that we have and when you think about what it can be in the future. And somebody said to me the other day, what do you think is going to happen in the next generation, the next hundred years? And I said, oh, I think your second home will be on the moon. Probably.

segments.speaker: Great-Granddaughter
segments.text: What is the best advice that you've ever been given and who was it from?

segments.speaker: Gigi (Mary Shane Bird)
segments.text: The best advice I think was from my parents, my mother and my father. It was taking your own business and letting everybody else do their thing. I was born and raised on a farm and all they grew was cotton and corn.

segments.speaker: Gigi (Mary Shane Bird)
segments.text: And the only foods that we bought was flour and meal. We had our own chickens, our own cows, horses. They had a hen house.

segments.speaker: Gigi (Mary Shane Bird)
segments.text: The hens went in a house to lay their eggs and my job was to pick up the eggs every day and bring them to the house.

segments.speaker: Great-Granddaughter
segments.text: What story from your life would you like me to pass on to my grandchildren?

segments.speaker: Gigi (Mary Shane Bird)
segments.text: When I graduated from high school, it was during the Great Depression in the 1930s and I needed a job. And I got a job as a waitress making a dollar a day and my uniforms.

segments.speaker: Gigi (Mary Shane Bird)
segments.text: And my father came to see me about three weeks later and he said, Mary, how much money do you make? And proudly I said, a dollar a day and my uniforms. And he said, you know what you do with 10 cents of that dollar don't you? You give it to charity. And I said, but I've only got a dollar.

segments.speaker: Gigi (Mary Shane Bird)
segments.text: He said, would it make a difference when you wake up in the morning whether you have 90 cents or you have a dollar? And that has stuck with me for over 80 years.

segments.speaker: Great-Granddaughter
segments.text: Do you remember what girls and women were expected to act like or dress like when you were growing up? How did they dress differently then than they do now?

segments.speaker: Gigi (Mary Shane Bird)
segments.text: We didn't wear shorts.

segments.speaker: Great-Granddaughter
segments.text: When you were younger, did you like to keep up with trends and styles that were popular or did you like to kind of follow your own style?

segments.speaker: Gigi (Mary Shane Bird)
segments.text: Well, we lived in the country so you didn't know very much about style.
